I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People's Republic of Bangladesh for the Second Crop Diversification Project.1 
 
2.  The project will foster commercialization of agriculture through interventions to promote 
diversification  into  high-value  crops  (HVCs)2 and  value  addition,  gender  mainstreaming,  and 
climate change adaptation. The project is market oriented and demand driven, and will increase 
farmers’ incomes and enhance food security in Bangladesh.3 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, is at high risk from climate change 
particularly because of its low-lying position along the Bay of Bengal. Poverty incidence in the west 
of the country is 14 percentage points higher than in the east.4 Land, and its cultivation, is the 
country’s most basic resource with more than 75% of the population directly or indirectly engaged 
in agriculture. Rice is the dominant crop contributing most to self-sufficiency in food grains and 
hence  food  security.  However,  the  emphasis  on  rice  production  has  resulted  in  increased 
dependency on imported food, particularly HVCs including fruit, which remain unaffordable to many 
poor  consumers.  Therefore,  increasing  HVC  production  is  of  critical  importance  for  reducing 
imports and enhancing affordable and varied nutritious diets for the poor. Fertile and well-drained 
soils, a varied climate that favors a range of crops, and low daily wage rates contribute to the 
comparative advantage for growing HVCs in Bangladesh. 
 
4.  The government’s overall objective in the National Agriculture Policy5 is to make the nation 
self-sufficient in food and ensure a dependable food security system by increasing production of all 
crops,  including  HVCs.  In  the  National  Strategy  for  Accelerated  Poverty  Reduction  II,  the 
government gives highest priority to the development of the agriculture sector in addressing and 
rapidly reducing poverty, and reaffirms its commitment to make the country self-sufficient in food by 
2013.6 The  strategy  outlines  medium-term  policies  and  strategies  to  foster  agriculture  sector 
growth  that  include  (i)  increasing  crop  yield,  (ii)  providing  broad-based  policy  support,  (iii) 
diversifying  into  HVCs,  (iv)  intensifying  agricultural  research  and  technology  generation,  (v) 
disseminating technology among farmers, (vi) revamping the agricultural marketing system, (vii) 
promoting agroprocessing activities, (viii) adopting climate change adaptive technologies, and (ix) 
undertaking irrigation schemes and flood protection measures. The Second Crop Diversification 
Project  directly  supports  government  policy  on  food  security  and  agriculture  sector  growth, 
particularly for the following intervention areas prioritized in the National Food Policy Plan of 
Action: (i) agricultural marketing and trade (reducing marketing costs of agricultural products and 
strengthening value-chain integration), (ii) agricultural diversification into HVCs and a focus on 
involving  women,  (iii)  agricultural  credit  (increasing  formal  credit  to  agriculture,  especially  to 
marginal, small, and medium farmers), and (iv) market infrastructure development.7

5.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is supporting inclusive economic growth and poverty 
reduction in Bangladesh through its strategic priorities as identified in the country strategy and 
program for 2006–2010.8 The project is a follow-on to the successful ADB-assisted Northwest Crop 
Diversification  Project  (NCDP)  completed  in  June  2009.9 The  NCDP  substantially  raised  the 
incomes of small and marginal farmers in the northwest region.10 The proposed project will build on 
the  successful  NCDP  activities  and  expand  into  new  areas,  especially  the  southwest  of 
Bangladesh.  The  project  will  complement  the  NCDP  and  other  ADB  support,  such  as  the 
Agribusiness  Development  Project, 11  particularly  by  promoting  value  addition  to  HVCs, 
strengthening  value-chain  integration  by  developing  backward  and  forward  linkages  between 
farmers and consumers, and including service provision by private sector agribusinesses and 
technically and financially qualified microfinance institutions (MFIs) and wholesale banks. 
 
6.  The  project  is  consistent  with  the  ADB  country  strategy  and  in  conformity  with 
recommendations made in the recent country assistance program evaluation in Bangladesh.12 The 
evaluation found that lack of agricultural diversification is one of the country's binding constraints to 
growth, and confirmed that agricultural and rural development is one of the government's top 
priorities and key to reducing rural poverty. The project is also consistent with the ADB Operational 
Plan for Sustainable Food Security,13 which suggests enhancing ADB’s multisector food security 
engagement by increasing synergy and value addition in backward and forward linkages along the 
food and agriculture value chain, with particular attention to small farmers and farm households 
headed by women and other vulnerable groups. The project will be a pioneer in mainstreaming 
climate  change  adaptation  into  project  design  and  implementation,  following  the  South  Asia 
Department  Climate  Change  Implementation  Plan  for  Bangladesh. 14  Climate-resilient  crop 
varieties, and cropping patterns and technology will be tested and disseminated to help farmers 
adapt to climate change. 
 
7.  The project will actively pursue liaison, cooperation, and synergies with other development 
partners, including (i) the World Bank-assisted National Agricultural Technology Project, 2008–
2013; (ii) Danish International Development Agency-assisted Agricultural Sector Program Support 
Phase  II,  2006–2011;  (iii)  ADB  and  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development-assisted 
Participatory Small-Scale Water Resources Sector Project, 2009–2017; (iv) Islamic Development 
Bank-assisted Greater Rangpur District Agricultural and Rural Development Project, 2006–2011; 
and (v) Food and Agriculture Organization-supported Livelihood Adaptation to Climate Change 
Project, which is piloting short-, medium-, and long-term climate adaptation changes for farmers. 
 
8.  The  project  design  incorporates  lessons  from  other  projects  in  the  agriculture  sector, 
particularly the NCDP, including the following: 
(i)  Agriculture projects continue to be important for promoting social inclusiveness, 
particularly of women and ethnic minorities, in the economic development process 
and for reducing income poverty by creating opportunities for employment and asset 
creation.  Given  the  shrinking  availability  of  arable  land  (decreasing  by  1%  per

annum), sector growth must come from productivity gains linked to more intensive 
land use and diversification into HVCs. 
(ii)  Access to finance is essential for farmers. Providing a very small agricultural loan is 
expensive for banks, and obtaining such a loan from banks is inconvenient, difficult, 
and costly for a farmer. Credit through MFIs enables farmers investing in HVCs. 
(iii)  Project  planning  and  implementation  must  involve  grassroots  stakeholders  and 
avoid use of top–down approaches. Farmer organizations involving women and 
small farmers need to be strengthened to increase their bargaining capability.  
(iv)  More cooperation between the public and private sectors is necessary to ensure 
progress in commercializing agriculture. 
(v)  Effective linkages with external markets are needed for women, considering their 
realities in the community. Disseminating labor-saving and postharvest technology 
is important for women's health and for reducing the postharvest work burden for 
school-age children. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be increased rural income in 27 districts of the southwest and northwest of 
Bangladesh. The outcome will be improved efficiency and value addition of HVC production. The 
direct beneficiaries will be marginal, small and medium farmers with landholdings up to 3 hectares. 
Landless  people  will  benefit  through  generated  employment  opportunities  in  rural  areas.  The 
project area, comprising (i) 43 upazilas (subdistricts) in 18 districts of Barisal, Dhaka, and Khulna 
divisions in the southwest; and (ii) 9 upazilas in 9 districts of Rajshahi and Rangpur divisions in the 
northwest,15 contains some of the country's poorest people and least economically developed and 
most climate-vulnerable16 areas. The project focus helps address the growing east–west divide in 
the incidence of poverty and economic development of the country. 
 
C.  Outputs 
10.  Outputs include (i) increased HVC production and commercialization; (ii) reduced HVC 
postharvest losses, improved product quality and value addition, and enhanced market efficiency; 
(iii) enhanced capacity of public sector institutions and participating partners to support farmers to 
increase  their  incomes;  and  (iv)  increased  participation  of  women  in  commercial  agricultural 
activities. The outputs will be delivered through five components. 
 
1.  High-Value Crop Production Support 
11.  Project farmers will be provided with the latest HVC production technology using lessons 
from the NCDP and closely consulting with farmers. Extension will be through institutional and 
field-based  training,  demonstration  plots  and  cross-field  learning,  dissemination  of  brochures, 
motivational tours, agricultural fairs, and ongoing extension services provided by the Department of 
Agricultural Extension (DAE). Technologies will include integrated pest management techniques; 
reduced and zero tillage practices; green and organic manure application; controlled environment 
agricultural technology; and mechanization for cultivation, harvesting, and postharvest handling. 
High-quality planting material will be supplied to farmers from the horticulture development training

center (HDTC) nurseries.17 Women will be trained, equally with men, and have equal access to all 
project benefits. 
 
12.  The focus will be on crops with a proven market demand, high profitability per hectare, and 
potential for commercialization in comparison to high-yielding boro rice. A range of high-value 
fruits, vegetable, pulses, and spices will be supported as well as cut flowers, potted plants and 
foliage production, and value addition to coconuts (such as coir and virgin coconut oil production). 
Profitable farming systems involving intercropping will be promoted. The project will pilot test 
climate-resilient (drought-, flood-, and saline-tolerant) varieties of crops to facilitate adaptation by 
HVC farmers. These activities will focus on pilot locations in drought-prone areas in the northwest, 
and  areas  vulnerable  to  cyclones,  flood  surges,  and  salinity  in  the  southwest,  following  a 
vulnerability assessment to develop effective adaptation options and strategies. 
 
2.  Value Addition Support 
13.  To take advantage of value addition options and improve marketing efficiency, marginal, 
small and medium farmers must aggregate their produce to achieve the necessary economy of 
scale, capacity, or knowledge to operate beyond the basic farm-gate level. The project will provide 
farmers and farmer community groups18 with training and awareness-raising in value addition 
options  to  improve  their  production  and  marketing  decisions,  and  increase  their  marketing 
efficiency and profitability. 
 
14.  To reduce postharvest losses and improve produce quality on a cost-sharing basis, the 
project will support farmer community investment in low-cost, on-farm, small-scale infrastructure 
(OFSSI), which may include (i) on-farm (or near-farm) collection and postharvest handling centers, 
including washing, drying, sorting, grading, and packaging facilities; and (ii) small-scale cool, cold, 
and dry storage and market-related transport facilities. Farmer communities, supported by DAE 
and contracted service providers, will be responsible for identifying the investment, preparing and 
submitting a proposal to the project management unit (PMU) for evaluation, providing land, and 
operating and maintaining the OFSSI facilities. The Local Government Engineering Department 
(LGED), under a memorandum of understanding, will assist the PMU in evaluating proposals and 
contractors to be hired through a PMU-led tendering process. LGED field staff will supervise 
construction works through to completion. 
 
3.  Credit Support 
15.  Funds required for HVC diversification exceed the savings of most small farmers.19 The 
project will provide access to credit to about 175,000 HVC farmers through financially sound MFIs 
experienced  in  agriculture  credit,  following  a  similar  and  successful  partnership  approach 
demonstrated under the NCDP and the Agribusiness Development Project. Credit phasing will 
follow and be linked to DAE farmer training and the establishment of demonstration plots. 
 
4.  Institutional Strengthening 
16.  Trainers and staff in DAE and participating MFIs, at upazila and district levels, will be 
instructed on the provision of training and extension services in HVC production and value addition

training. Training will cover gender awareness and environmental issues, including adaptation of 
farming systems to climate change. 
 
17.  Following surveys and needs assessments, DAE district and upazila offices and HDTCs, 
primarily in the southwest, will be rehabilitated and equipped. Vehicles will be provided, mainly in 
the  upazilas,  to  facilitate  communication  between  project  implementers  and  farmers,  and  to 
transport planting and other necessary materials for farmer field days and demonstrations. The 
project will undertake a feasibility study on setting up a quality standards certification system for 
fruits and vegetables farms to facilitate access to domestic retail markets, including supermarkets, 
and to reduce food contamination. 
 
5.  Project Implementation Support 
18.  A PMU and two regional project implementation units (PIUs) will provide implementation 
support, comprising staff, office facilities and equipment, transport, consulting services, and liaison 
and development coordination with other ministries and development partners. The PMU will hire 
one community facilitator for each upazila to (i) assist DAE staff in identifying communities, and 
mobilizing  and  training  farmers  interested  in  participating  in  the  project;  
(ii) help with gender awareness activities; (iii) liaise with MFIs; and (iv) help promote value addition 
activities within communities. A project performance management system will be established. 
Baseline  surveys,  and  regular  monitoring  and  evaluation  will  be  undertaken.  The  PMU  will 
establish and maintain a project website to disclose information about project activities, including 
procurement procedures and results. LGED will appoint a project coordinator to liaise with DAE on 
OFSSI activities.

20.  The government has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR27,131,000 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 32-year term, 
including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and 
project agreements. The interest on the loan will be capitalized during the grace period. 
 
21.  The  ADB  loan  of  $40  million  equivalent  will  finance  87%  of  the  project  cost.  The 
government is to provide $5.42 million equivalent to finance 12% of the project cost including (i) 
50%  of  district  agriculture  offices  and  HDTC  upgrading  cost;  (ii)  100%  of  the  operation  and

will provide about $0.39 million equivalent to finance 1% of the project cost by contributing to 25% 
of the OFSSI construction cost (in kind and land contribution). The high local cost financing is 
justified given that the project is poverty-targeted and meets the financing demand for marginal, 
small, and medium farmers, which has low foreign exchange inputs. Table 2 summarizes the

23.  Bangladesh Bank will be responsible for managing and overseeing the flow of funds for the 
credit line (component 3), assisted by BASIC Bank, Eastern Bank, and participating MFIs that meet 
the project's selection criteria. An MFI selection committee comprising the project director, and

and Eastern Bank will be responsible for the final selection of up to 10 participating MFIs based on 
the selection criteria and financial due diligence assessments. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
24.  Adoption of HVCs will lead to increased agricultural productivity and more sustainable 
resource  use,  and  contribute  to  more  flexible  and  adaptive  management  of  climate  change 
impacts. The project will lead to increased HVC production, greater diversification of sources of 
income, and higher net returns for marginal, small and medium farmers. Direct project beneficiaries 
will include about 240,000 HVC-growing households, of which 175,000 will receive credit. The 
project is expected to generate more than 37,500 person-years of annual employment; much of 
this employment will be among landless rural workers, including women. The financial internal rate 
of return of the project over 15 years is estimated at 46.7% and the economic internal rate of return 
at 38.6%. Sensitivity analyses incorporating a range of feasible risks show economic internal rates 
of return range from 24% to 38%. These risks cover a 20% decline in the project area and 20%

8 
decline in crop yields. The economic internal rates of return indicate the project is robust and 
attractive from an investment point of view. 
 
B.  Governance 
25.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government of Bangladesh, DAE and Bangladesh Bank. The specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual. 
 
26.  DAE and Bangladesh Bank have implemented numerous aid-assisted projects and have 
the organizational structure, skills, and financial management system to implement the project. A 
procurement  assessment  found  that  DAE  had  satisfactory  procurement  capacity.  A  financial 
management assessment and due diligence were completed for the proposed executing agencies 
and  participating  financial  institutions.  Project-specific  measures  to  enhance  governance  and 
prevent corruption include (i) advance selection of the wholesale banks on the basis of agreed 
criteria; (ii) formation of a committee of stakeholders to select participating MFIs according to 
agreed criteria; (iii) use of standardized procedures of Bangladesh Bank in its supervision of 
wholesale banks and, through them, the MFIs; (iv) the requirement for the PMU and PIUs to follow 
government rules and procedures for all expense and capital items, including cash, and to properly 
maintain financial records; and (v) establishment of a project website at the PMU to provide 
transparency  on  project  details  including  procurement.  Further,  within  9  months  of  project 
effectiveness,  the  PMU  will  prepare  a  grievance  redress  mechanism  acceptable  to  ADB.  An 
independent  auditor  acceptable  to  ADB  will  annually  audit  all  project-related  accounts  and 
statements of expenditure and revenue, and provide a separate audit opinion on the use of the 
imprest accounts and statement of expenditure procedure. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
27.  The project will contribute to economic growth and food security as well as directly benefit 
the poor by creating employment opportunities in HVC on-farm and off-farm activities. Poor farmers 
will benefit from increased incomes due to returns from crop production and increased value 
addition through marketing interventions. The landless poor will benefit as agricultural laborers due 
to the creation of additional employment opportunities in HVCs and ancillary industries. Of the 
anticipated 240,000 HVC farmer beneficiaries, 122,800 (50.8%) are living below the poverty line. In 
the southwest and northwest areas, 51% of agricultural households are poor compared with 37% 
in divisions outside the project area. The project will raise incomes of farmers by Tk73,000 per 
hectare of HVC. Poor households growing HVCs will benefit from increased labor employment of 
Tk3,230 per household and Tk12,170 from increased crop income based on an average 0.167 
hectares in HVC production per household. In total, this represents an increase in income of 
Tk15,400 per household (40% increase). 
 
28.  The project will have a positive impact on gender equality. The number of women involved 
in commercial agricultural activities is expected to increase by 10% by the end of the project in 
2016. Women will improve their knowledge and capacity to undertake HVC production, postharvest 
handling, and marketing activities through institutional and field-based training and participation in 
women’s forum groups. Furthermore, the use of MFIs as credit providers, with their pro-women 
attitude, will ensure greater involvement of women as loan recipients (20% increase by 2016) and 
in cosigning loans with their husbands. Participation in the project activities, as observed in the 
NCDP, will raise the social standing of women in the communities and improve their access to a 
broader range of services.

9 
D.  Safeguards 
 
29.  Safeguards  were  categorized  for  the  project.  The  project  falls  under  category  C  for 
involuntary resettlement, B for indigenous people, and B for environment. The envisioned project 
interventions will not entail adverse social or resettlement impacts. The project will work with 
farmers working on their own or leased land. Limited construction will be on government land, 
existing rights-of-way, or lands owned by the beneficiaries themselves. The project will exclude any 
subprojects that entail land acquisition or any involuntary resettlement including relocation. The 
project  will  use  surveys  to  identify  the  presence  of  indigenous  people  when  starting  project 
implementation in each project upazila. If identified, the indigenous people will be supported to be 
involved in crop diversification and value addition activities, through developing and implementing 
an indigenous people action plan as specified in the indigenous peoples development framework 
following ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
 
30.  The project may have minor adverse environmental impacts like soil erosion, and harmful 
effects  from  inappropriate  use  of  chemical  fertilizers  and  pesticides  by  farmers  not  yet  fully 
knowledgeable  concerning  recommended  techniques.  Measures  to  mitigate  such  effects  and 
monitoring  and  compliance  tasks  are  outlined  in  the  initial  environment  examination  and 
environmental assessment and review procedures to ensure the project's compliance with ADB’s 
Environment Policy (2002) and all applicable environmental laws and regulations of Bangladesh. 
Special consideration will be given to the potential impacts of climate change on the project goals 
to promote HVCs; the project incorporates detailed adaptation options including developing and 
disseminating new climate change-resilient crop species. Moreover, actions and measures are 
included to strengthen the in-house capacity of DAE in dealing with environmental issues with 
special reference to climate change impacts.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
32.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption,  safeguards,  gender, 
procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in the project administration 
manual and loan documents. 
 
33.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set 
forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
34.  Conditions for disbursement. No disbursement will be made into imprest accounts of the 
project until a project director with the requisite skills, experience, and capacities necessary for the 
project and satisfactory to ADB has been appointed and the PMU and the two PIUs have been 
established and are operating in a manner satisfactory to ADB. 
 
35.  No disbursement will be made into the imprest account for the credit support component of 
the project until 
 
(i)  the subsidiary loan agreement between the Finance Division and Bangladesh Bank, 
and wholesale bank financing agreements between Bangladesh Bank and each of 
BASIC Bank and Eastern Bank, have been signed and delivered to ADB in form and 
substance satisfactory to ADB; 
(ii)  the committee for selection of participating MFIs has been established with five 
members, approved by ADB, representing the project director, Bangladesh Bank 
Agricultural Credit Department, Microcredit Regulatory Authority, and each of the 
two wholesale banks; and 
(iii)  ADB has received not less than one executed onlending agreement between at 
least one wholesale bank and at least one participating MFI, selected in compliance 
with the agreed criteria, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR27,131,000 to the People's Republic of Bangladesh for the Second 
Crop Diversification Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate 
of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
